shortDescription: Popular tropical plant with large split leaves that develop distinctive holes as it matures. Grows quickly in bright indirect light and adapts well to indoor conditions.
notes: Provide a moss pole or support for climbing. Wipe leaves regularly to remove dust.

shortDescription: One of the easiest houseplants to grow with heart-shaped variegated leaves. Tolerates low light and occasional neglect exceptionally well.
notes: Trim regularly to encourage bushier growth. Can be propagated easily in water.

shortDescription: Extremely hardy plant with upright sword-like leaves featuring distinctive patterns. Tolerates neglect and survives in almost any light condition.
notes: Overwatering is the main cause of death. Allow soil to dry completely between waterings.

shortDescription: Nearly indestructible plant with glossy dark green leaves that grow in graceful wand-like stems. Thrives on neglect and low light conditions.
notes: Rhizomes store water, so water sparingly. Yellow leaves indicate overwatering.

shortDescription: Graceful arching foliage with green and white striped leaves that produce small plantlets on hanging stems. Safe for pets and excellent for beginners.
notes: Brown tips indicate fluoride sensitivity or low humidity. Propagate easily from plantlets.

shortDescription: Popular flowering plant with elegant white blooms and glossy dark green leaves. Thrives in low light and communicates water needs by drooping.
notes: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Mist regularly for humidity.

shortDescription: Dramatic statement plant with large violin-shaped leaves. Requires consistent care and dislikes being moved or environmental changes.
notes: Water when top 2 inches of soil are dry. Rotate regularly for even growth. Sensitive to drafts.

shortDescription: Bold plant with thick glossy leaves that can range from dark green to burgundy. Grows into an impressive indoor tree with proper care.
notes: Wipe leaves regularly to maintain shine. Prune to control height and encourage bushiness.

shortDescription: Medicinal succulent with thick fleshy leaves containing soothing gel. Requires minimal care and bright light to thrive.
notes: Allow soil to dry completely between waterings. Gel can be used for minor burns and skin irritation.

shortDescription: Classic succulent with thick oval leaves and woody stems that resembles a miniature tree. Can live for decades with proper care.
notes: Water deeply but infrequently. Red edges on leaves indicate good sun exposure.

shortDescription: Fast-growing trailing plant with heart-shaped leaves featuring striking lime-green variegation. Extremely easy to care for and propagate.
notes: Brighter light enhances variegation. Propagates easily from stem cuttings in water.

shortDescription: Stunning plant with dark green leaves featuring pink pinstripe patterns. Leaves fold up at night and requires high humidity to thrive.
notes: Use filtered or distilled water. Mist daily or use a humidifier. Avoid direct sunlight.

shortDescription: Unique succulent with cascading strands of bead-like leaves. Requires bright light and careful watering to prevent rot.
notes: Water from below to avoid wetting the pearls. Prune to encourage fuller growth.

shortDescription: Classic fern with arching fronds covered in delicate leaflets. Requires consistent moisture and high humidity to prevent browning.
notes: Keep soil consistently moist. Mist daily or place on a pebble tray. Trim brown fronds.

shortDescription: Dramatic tropical plant with large banana-like leaves. Can produce spectacular orange and blue flowers with sufficient light and maturity.
notes: Requires very bright light to flower indoors. Wipe dust from large leaves regularly.

shortDescription: Slender tree-like plant with narrow arching leaves edged in red. Tolerates neglect and low light conditions exceptionally well.
notes: Sensitive to fluoride in tap water. Use filtered water if leaf tips turn brown.

shortDescription: Popular flowering succulent with segmented trailing stems that produce vibrant blooms in winter. Blooms triggered by shorter days and cooler temperatures.
notes: Keep slightly moist during blooming. Reduce watering after flowering. Prefers being pot-bound.

shortDescription: Classic trailing vine with lobed leaves available in various colors and patterns. Versatile plant that can trail from baskets or climb supports.
notes: Prone to spider mites in dry conditions. Mist regularly and check undersides of leaves.

shortDescription: Stunning foliage plant with patterned leaves that fold upward at night like praying hands. Requires consistent moisture and humidity.
notes: Use distilled water to prevent brown edges. Never let soil dry out completely.

shortDescription: Charming compact plant with fuzzy leaves and vibrant flowers in purple, pink, or white. Blooms almost continuously with proper care.
notes: Water from below to avoid wetting leaves. Use room temperature water only.

shortDescription: Nearly indestructible plant with dark green lance-shaped leaves. Tolerates deep shade, neglect, and various temperature extremes.
notes: Perfect for difficult low-light corners. Slow-growing but extremely hardy.

shortDescription: Versatile foliage plant with colorful patterned leaves in shades of green, silver, pink, or red. Thrives in low light conditions.
notes: Avoid cold drafts and temperatures below 60°F. Wipe leaves to maintain vibrant patterns.

shortDescription: Popular orchid with elegant arching sprays of long-lasting blooms. Easier to care for than most orchid varieties.
notes: Grow in bark medium, not soil. Water weekly by soaking pot for 15 minutes. Avoid water in crown.

shortDescription: Tropical plant with glossy heart-shaped flowers in red, pink, or white that last for weeks. Requires warmth and humidity.
notes: The flower is actually a modified leaf called a spathe. Mist regularly for best results.

shortDescription: Vining succulent with thick waxy leaves that produces clusters of fragrant star-shaped flowers. Long-lived and easy to maintain.
notes: Never remove flower spurs after blooming as new flowers form on same spur. Prefers being pot-bound.

shortDescription: Compact plant with thick glossy leaves that stores water in its stems. Perfect for small spaces and beginners.
notes: Prone to root rot if overwatered. Allow top half of soil to dry between waterings.

shortDescription: Graceful small palm with delicate fronds that thrives in low light. Perfect for adding tropical feel to any room.
notes: Mist regularly to prevent spider mites. Brown tips indicate low humidity or fluoride in water.

shortDescription: Fast-growing plant with glossy leaves arranged like umbrella spokes. Tolerates various conditions and pruning well.
notes: Prune regularly to maintain bushy shape. Can grow quite large if not trimmed.

shortDescription: Striking plant with triangular purple leaves that fold down at night and delicate pink flowers. Goes dormant periodically.
notes: Leaves fold down at night or in low light. Allow dormancy period by reducing water when leaves die back.

shortDescription: Fast-growing trailing plant with striped purple and silver leaves. Extremely easy to propagate and maintain.
notes: Pinch back regularly to encourage bushier growth. Propagates easily from cuttings.

shortDescription: Spherical cactus with distinctive golden spines arranged in neat rows. Very slow-growing and drought-tolerant.
notes: Needs full sun to maintain color. Water sparingly in winter. Handle carefully due to sharp spines.

shortDescription: Vibrant tropical plant with multicolored leaves in yellow, orange, red, and green. Requires bright light to maintain vivid colors.
notes: Drops leaves when moved or stressed. Requires consistent warmth and humidity.

shortDescription: Charming plant with round coin-shaped leaves on delicate stems. Produces many offshoots that can be easily propagated.
notes: Rotate regularly for even growth. Produces baby plants at base that can be separated.

shortDescription: Ornamental plant grown for spectacular patterned leaves in metallic colors and swirling designs. Requires humidity and consistent care.
notes: Avoid getting water on leaves. Prefers bottom watering. May go dormant in winter.

shortDescription: Striking architectural plant with sword-like leaves growing from woody stems. Extremely drought-tolerant and low-maintenance.
notes: Needs very bright light. Overwatering is the most common cause of problems.

shortDescription: Popular foliage plant with large variegated leaves in cream and green patterns. Fast-growing and tolerant of various conditions.
notes: Very toxic if ingested. Keep away from children and pets. Wipe dust from large leaves.

shortDescription: Small succulent with distinctive white horizontal stripes on dark green pointed leaves. Perfect for beginners and small spaces.
notes: Prefers bright indirect light. Can tolerate some direct morning sun. Water sparingly.

shortDescription: Compact plant with intricately veined leaves in pink, white, or red against dark green. Dramatic when thirsty but recovers quickly.
notes: Wilts dramatically when dry but bounces back after watering. Thrives in terrariums.

shortDescription: Tropical plant with vibrant colorful bracts and rosette of strap-like leaves. Water collects in central cup formed by leaves.
notes: Fill central cup with water and change weekly. Mother plant dies after flowering but produces pups.

shortDescription: Soilless plant that absorbs water and nutrients through its leaves. Can be displayed creatively mounted or in terrariums.
notes: Soak in water for 20-30 minutes weekly. Shake off excess water and dry upside down. Mist between soakings.

shortDescription: Delicate feathery foliage that adds soft texture to any space. Actually not a true fern but a member of the lily family.
notes: Mist frequently to prevent needles from dropping. Produces tiny thorns on stems. Dislikes being moved.

shortDescription: Colorful plant with leaves spotted in pink, red, or white. Fast-growing and responds well to pinching for bushier growth.
notes: Pinch back regularly to prevent legginess. Can become leggy if light is too low.

shortDescription: Popular plant often grown in water with distinctive bamboo-like stalks. Easy to care for and considered lucky in feng shui.
notes: Can grow in water or soil. Change water weekly if growing in water. Use filtered water.

shortDescription: Cheerful flowering succulent with clusters of small bright blooms in various colors. Long-lasting flowers and easy care requirements.
notes: Deadhead spent flowers to encourage reblooming. Needs short days to trigger flowering.

shortDescription: Dramatic tropical plant with large arrow-shaped leaves featuring striking white veins. Requires high humidity and consistent care.
notes: Very sensitive to water quality. Use filtered water. May go dormant in winter. Keep away from cold drafts.

shortDescription: Delicate trailing succulent with heart-shaped variegated leaves on thin purple stems. Produces small tubular flowers and aerial tubers.
notes: Grows from tubers that store water. Prune to encourage fuller growth. Propagate from tubers or cuttings.

shortDescription: Tropical trailing plant that produces tubular red flowers emerging from dark maroon buds resembling lipstick tubes. Glossy foliage cascades beautifully.
notes: Needs bright indirect light to bloom. Mist regularly for humidity. Prefers being slightly pot-bound for best flowering.

shortDescription: Classic Mediterranean flowering plant with vibrant blooms in red, pink, or white. Extremely popular on Spanish balconies and patios.
notes: Deadhead regularly for continuous blooming. Tolerates heat and drought well. Bring indoors during frost.

shortDescription: Aromatic Mediterranean plant with purple flowers and silvery foliage. Native to Spain and thrives in hot, dry conditions.
notes: Prune after flowering. Requires excellent drainage. Can be dried for sachets and aromatherapy.

shortDescription: Woody aromatic herb with needle-like leaves and blue flowers. Essential in Mediterranean cuisine and grows wild throughout Spain.
notes: Harvest regularly to encourage growth. Excellent drainage is critical. Can grow into a large shrub.

shortDescription: Popular culinary herb with fragrant green leaves. Thrives in Spanish summers and widely available in markets and nurseries.
notes: Pinch off flowers to promote leaf growth. Harvest from the top to encourage bushiness. Water regularly.

shortDescription: Evergreen shrub with showy flowers in pink, white, or red. Extremely common in Spanish landscapes and very heat-tolerant.
notes: All parts are highly toxic. Wear gloves when pruning. Extremely drought-tolerant once established.

shortDescription: Spectacular climbing plant with vibrant papery bracts in magenta, purple, or orange. Iconic plant of Spanish courtyards and patios.
notes: Needs full sun to bloom profusely. Thorny stems require careful handling. Drought-tolerant once established.

shortDescription: Fragrant climbing plant with white star-shaped flowers. Commonly grown in Spanish gardens for its intoxicating evening scent.
notes: Flowers have strongest fragrance at night. Prune after flowering. Provide support for climbing.

shortDescription: Iconic Mediterranean tree with silvery-green foliage and edible fruit. Symbol of Spanish agriculture and culture.
notes: Extremely drought-tolerant. Can be grown in large containers. Requires winter chill for fruit production.

shortDescription: Iconic cactus with flat paddle-shaped segments and edible fruits. Naturalized throughout Spain and part of traditional cuisine.
notes: Fruits and pads are edible. Handle carefully due to glochids. Extremely drought-tolerant.

shortDescription: Fragrant citrus tree producing bright yellow fruits. Widely cultivated in Spain, especially Valencia and Andalusia.
notes: Needs consistent watering and fertilization. Can be grown in containers. Protect from frost.

shortDescription: Iconic Spanish citrus tree with fragrant white blossoms and sweet fruit. Lines streets in cities like Sevilla.
notes: Needs regular watering and feeding. Fragrant spring blooms. Can take several years to fruit.

shortDescription: Dramatic succulent with thick spiny blue-green leaves forming large rosettes. Common in Spanish xeriscaping and coastal areas.
notes: Extremely sharp leaf tips. Flowers once before dying but produces offsets. Very drought-tolerant.

shortDescription: Only palm native to Europe, common throughout Spanish coast. Compact fan-shaped fronds and multi-stemmed growth.
notes: Highly cold-hardy for a palm. Tolerates coastal salt spray. Slow-growing but very hardy.

shortDescription: Majestic palm with massive crown of feather fronds. Symbol of Spanish coastal cities and promenades.
notes: Needs space to grow large. Sharp spines on leaf bases. Very drought-tolerant once established.

shortDescription: Low-growing aromatic herb with tiny leaves and purple flowers. Native to Mediterranean and essential in Spanish cooking.
notes: Excellent drainage required. Harvest regularly. Attracts bees when flowering.

shortDescription: Aromatic Mediterranean herb with small oval leaves. Essential in Spanish cuisine and grows wild in many regions.
notes: Flavor is strongest when dried. Cut back after flowering. Very drought-tolerant.

shortDescription: Silvery-leaved aromatic herb with purple flower spikes. Common in Spanish gardens and markets.
notes: Prune in spring to maintain shape. Excellent drainage required. Can be used fresh or dried.

shortDescription: Vigorous aromatic herb with fresh fragrant leaves. Popular in Spanish mojitos and teas.
notes: Very invasive - grow in containers. Keep soil moist. Harvest frequently for best flavor.

shortDescription: Essential culinary herb with bright green curled or flat leaves. Staple in Spanish kitchens and widely available.
notes: Biennial but grown as annual. Harvest outer leaves first. Keep soil consistently moist.

shortDescription: Popular winter-flowering plant with upswept petals in pink, red, or white. Very common in Spanish flower shops during autumn and winter.
notes: Prefers cool temperatures. Water from below. Goes dormant in summer. Remove spent flowers.

shortDescription: Trailing geranium with ivy-shaped leaves and cascading flowers. Extremely popular in Spanish balcony boxes.
notes: Deadhead regularly. More heat-tolerant than zonal geraniums. Perfect for hanging baskets.

shortDescription: Popular annual with trumpet-shaped flowers in many colors. Extremely common in Spanish gardens and balconies.
notes: Deadhead regularly for continuous blooms. Feed weekly. Can become leggy in extreme heat.

shortDescription: Bright orange or yellow flowering annual with distinctive scent. Popular in Spanish vegetable gardens as pest deterrent.
notes: Deadhead for more flowers. Attracts beneficial insects. Natural pest repellent for tomatoes.

shortDescription: Fragrant ruffled flowers in many colors with grassy foliage. Important in Spanish culture, especially in Andalusia.
notes: Deadhead to prolong flowering. Provide good air circulation. Popular cut flower.

shortDescription: Spectacular tropical plant with large showy flowers in vibrant colors. Popular in Spanish coastal gardens.
notes: Needs consistent watering. Flowers last only one day. Bring indoors during winter in northern Spain.

shortDescription: Tropical fern with glossy, wavy-edged fronds forming a nest-like rosette. Available in Spanish plant shops.
notes: Avoid touching new fronds. Keep center of rosette dry. Mist regularly for humidity.

shortDescription: Delicate fern with lacy fronds on black wiry stems. Requires high humidity but popular in Spanish plant shops.
notes: Very sensitive to dry air and tap water. Use distilled water. Never let soil dry out.

shortDescription: Unique fern with antler-shaped fronds that can be mounted on boards. Increasingly popular in Spanish interior design.
notes: Can be mounted or potted. Mist regularly. Brown shield fronds are normal.

shortDescription: Rosette-forming succulent with powdery blue-green leaves. Very popular in Spanish succulent arrangements.
notes: Avoid getting leaves wet. Excellent drainage required. Produces offsets for propagation.

shortDescription: Trailing succulent with plump teardrop-shaped leaves on cascading stems. Popular in Spanish hanging baskets.
notes: Leaves fall off easily when touched. Needs bright light to maintain compact growth. Drought-tolerant.

shortDescription: Stacked succulent with triangular leaves that appear strung on stems. Unusual form popular in Spanish succulent collections.
notes: Excellent drainage essential. Leaves turn pink in bright light. Water sparingly.

shortDescription: Tree-like succulent with rosettes of glossy leaves on branching stems. Native to Canary Islands and popular throughout Spain.
notes: Goes dormant in summer heat. Water more in winter growing season. Can grow quite large.

shortDescription: Striking succulent with cylindrical blue-grey leaves arranged in spirals. Increasingly popular in Spanish succulent gardens.
notes: Excellent drainage critical. Blue color intensifies in bright light. Propagates easily from cuttings.

shortDescription: Hardy succulent forming tight rosettes in various colors. Found in Spanish mountain regions and popular in rockeries.
notes: Extremely cold-hardy. Rosettes die after flowering but produce many offsets. Needs excellent drainage.

shortDescription: Elegant palm with arching dark green fronds. Popular in Spanish hotels, restaurants, and homes.
notes: Tolerates low light better than most palms. Slow-growing. Wipe dust from fronds regularly.

shortDescription: Clustering palm with golden-yellow stems and feathery fronds. Common in Spanish indoor spaces.
notes: Brown tips indicate low humidity or fluoride. Mist regularly. Remove yellowing fronds.

shortDescription: Compact palm with fan-shaped leaves and bamboo-like stems. Tolerates low light and available in Spanish nurseries.
notes: Very slow-growing. Tolerates neglect well. Expensive due to slow growth rate.

shortDescription: Symmetrical coniferous tree with soft needle-like foliage. Popular as indoor Christmas tree in Spain.
notes: Mist regularly for humidity. Rotate for even growth. Can grow quite tall indoors.

shortDescription: Compact variety of umbrella plant with rounded glossy leaflets. Very popular in Spanish apartments.
notes: More compact than regular umbrella plant. Prune to maintain shape. Wipe leaves to maintain shine.

shortDescription: Vining monstera with smaller leaves full of natural holes. Increasingly trendy in Spanish plant shops.
notes: Can trail or climb with support. Propagates easily in water. Similar care to Monstera deliciosa.

shortDescription: Trailing plant with heart-shaped leaves splashed with silver markings. Popular alternative to pothos in Spanish homes.
notes: Less vigorous than golden pothos. Silver markings need adequate light. Easy to propagate.

shortDescription: Highly variegated pothos variety with white and green marbled leaves. Common in Spanish plant collections.
notes: Needs more light than golden pothos for variegation. Can revert to green in low light. Easy care.

shortDescription: Classic trailing philodendron with glossy heart-shaped leaves. Very common and affordable in Spanish nurseries.
notes: One of the easiest houseplants. Can climb or trail. Propagates readily in water.

shortDescription: Compact philodendron with deeply lobed leaves growing in upright clumps. Popular in Spanish indoor landscapes.
notes: Non-climbing variety. More compact than other philodendrons. Easy care and forgiving.

shortDescription: Arrow-shaped leaves that change form as plant matures. Available in many color varieties in Spanish shops.
notes: Leaf shape changes from arrow to lobed as it climbs. Propagates easily. Many color varieties available.

shortDescription: Stunning trailing plant with pink, purple, and green striped leaves. Trendy variety in Spanish plant shops.
notes: Pinch back for bushier growth. Bright light enhances colors. Very easy to propagate.

shortDescription: Striking plant with deep purple foliage and pink flowers. Used as ground cover in Spanish gardens.
notes: Purple color intensifies in full sun. Very drought-tolerant. Can become invasive outdoors.

shortDescription: Colorful foliage plant with leaves in reds, purples, greens, and yellows. Popular in Spanish gardens and containers.
notes: Pinch flowers to promote foliage. Easy to propagate from cuttings. Many color varieties available.

shortDescription: Popular shade-loving annual with continuous bright flowers. Common in shaded Spanish balconies and patios.
notes: Excellent for shade. Keep soil consistently moist. Deadhead not necessary for continuous blooms.

shortDescription: Popular flowering annual with glossy leaves and clusters of blooms. Widely used in Spanish public gardens.
notes: Deadhead spent flowers. Tolerates heat well. Can be grown as houseplant in bright light.

shortDescription: Elegant hanging plant with pendulous two-toned flowers. Popular in cooler regions of Spain.
notes: Prefers cool temperatures. Dislikes hot afternoon sun. Keep consistently moist. Popular in northern Spain.

shortDescription: Cheerful winter-flowering annual with face-like blooms. Very popular in Spanish winter gardens.
notes: Cold-hardy. Deadhead regularly. Best in cool weather. Popular for winter color.

shortDescription: Early spring flowering plant with colorful blooms and rosette of leaves. Popular in Spanish spring gardens.
notes: Prefers cool weather. Keep soil moist. Deadhead for continuous blooms. Perennial in cool climates.

shortDescription: Daisy-like flowers in bright colors that close at night. Excellent for hot, dry Spanish gardens.
notes: Flowers open only in full sun. Very drought-tolerant. Deadhead to prolong blooming.

shortDescription: Low-growing succulent with bright ruffled flowers. Perfect for hot, dry Spanish summers.
notes: Flowers close at night and on cloudy days. Extremely drought-tolerant. Self-seeds readily.

shortDescription: Classic cheerful daisy with white petals and yellow centers. Common in Spanish lawns and meadows.
notes: Can be grown as perennial or annual. Deadhead for more flowers. Self-seeds readily.

shortDescription: Spectacular flowering plant with diverse bloom shapes and sizes. Popular in Spanish cut flower gardens.
notes: Stake tall varieties. Dig up tubers in cold areas. Deadhead regularly for continuous blooms.

shortDescription: Airy annual with feathery foliage and daisy-like flowers. Self-seeds readily in Spanish gardens.
notes: Very easy from seed. Self-seeds readily. Attracts butterflies. Tolerates poor soil.

shortDescription: Vibrant annual with long-lasting blooms in many colors. Popular in Spanish summer gardens.
notes: Deadhead for continuous blooms. Excellent cut flower. Provide good air circulation to prevent mildew.

shortDescription: Iconic tall plant with large yellow flower heads. Cultivated in Spanish fields and popular in gardens.
notes: Fast-growing annual. Stake tall varieties. Seeds attract birds. Many dwarf varieties available.

shortDescription: Edible flowering plant with round leaves and bright flowers. Both leaves and flowers used in Spanish salads.
notes: Flowers and leaves are edible with peppery taste. Poor soil produces more flowers. Attracts aphids away from other plants.

shortDescription: Low-growing annual with tiny fragrant flowers. Popular edging plant in Spanish gardens.
notes: Honey-scented flowers. Self-seeds readily. Excellent for borders and between pavers.

shortDescription: Climbing annual with intensely fragrant ruffled flowers. Popular in Spanish spring gardens.
notes: Prefers cool weather. Provide support for climbing. Pick flowers to encourage more blooms. Seeds are toxic.

shortDescription: Fast-growing vine with trumpet-shaped flowers that open in morning. Common on Spanish fences and trellises.
notes: Flowers close in afternoon. Provide strong support. Self-seeds readily. Can be invasive.

shortDescription: Vigorous climbing vine with orange flowers with dark centers. Popular annual vine in Spanish gardens.
notes: Fast-growing annual. Provide support. Deadhead for continuous blooms. Heat-tolerant.

shortDescription: Tropical climbing vine with large trumpet-shaped flowers in pink or red. Popular on Spanish terraces.
notes: Bring indoors in winter. Provide support for climbing. Feed regularly for continuous blooms.

shortDescription: Exotic climbing vine with intricate unusual flowers. Hardy variety that survives Spanish winters in mild areas.
notes: Can become invasive. Produces edible fruit. Provide strong support. Attracts butterflies.

shortDescription: Spectacular climbing vine with large showy flowers. Popular on Spanish walls and trellises.
notes: Keep roots cool and shaded, top in sun. Prune according to variety. Provide support.

shortDescription: Bushy tropical plant with glossy leaves and bright trumpet flowers. Very popular in Spanish containers.
notes: Bushier growth than Mandevilla. Feed regularly. Bring indoors in winter or treat as annual.

shortDescription: Succulent with large paddle-shaped leaves that turn red in bright light. Popular in Spanish succulent collections.
notes: Leaves turn brilliant red in full sun. Flowers once then dies but produces offsets. Drought-tolerant.

shortDescription: Hardy succulent forming tight rosettes that produce many offsets. Found in Spanish mountain regions.
notes: Extremely cold-hardy. Mother rosette dies after flowering. Needs excellent drainage. Many color varieties.

shortDescription: Thorny succulent with small bright flowers year-round. Popular in Spanish indoor collections.
notes: Sap is irritating to skin. Thorny stems. Flowers continuously in bright light. Very drought-tolerant.

shortDescription: Architectural succulent with pencil-thin stems. Increasingly popular in modern Spanish interiors.
notes: Highly toxic sap. Wear gloves when handling. Can grow very large. Turns orange-red in bright light.

shortDescription: Trailing succulent with plump rounded leaves on long stems. Popular in Spanish hanging containers.
notes: Leaves fall off very easily. Needs bright light. Can take years to reach full cascading length.

shortDescription: Unusual succulents resembling small stones with a split in the middle. Novelty plants in Spanish collections.
notes: Water very sparingly. Goes dormant in summer. Requires gritty, well-draining soil. Flowers emerge from split.

shortDescription: Succulent with fuzzy grey-green leaves edged in brown. Tactile favorite in Spanish plant shops.
notes: Soft fuzzy texture. Avoid getting leaves wet. Slow-growing. Easy care for beginners.

shortDescription: Unique plant with swollen trunk base and long curling leaves. Popular architectural plant in Spanish homes.
notes: Stores water in bulbous base. Very drought-tolerant. Slow-growing. Tolerates neglect well.

shortDescription: Small clustering cactus with colorful ring of flowers. Easy beginner cactus in Spanish collections.
notes: Flowers readily with proper care. Water sparingly. Many species available. Forms attractive clusters.

shortDescription: Columnar cactus covered in long white hair-like spines. Novelty cactus popular in Spanish shops.
notes: Hair protects from sun. Slow-growing. Water very sparingly. Full sun needed to maintain hair.

shortDescription: Trailing cactus with long tail-like stems and bright pink flowers. Unique hanging cactus in Spanish collections.
notes: Excellent for hanging baskets. Needs more water than typical cacti. Flowers in spring.

shortDescription: Spring-blooming cactus with star-shaped flowers in bright colors. Similar care to Christmas cactus.
notes: Blooms in spring. Needs more water than desert cacti. Prefer being slightly pot-bound.

shortDescription: Popular flowering plant with masses of blooms in many colors. Common gift plant in Spanish flower shops.
notes: Keep soil consistently moist. Prefers acidic soil. Remove spent flowers. Can be planted outdoors after blooming.

shortDescription: Showy shrub with large flower clusters in blue, pink, or white. Popular in gardens of northern Spain.
notes: Flower color depends on soil pH. Needs consistent moisture. Popular in Galicia and Asturias.

shortDescription: Popular vegetable plant producing edible fruits. Essential in Spanish vegetable gardens and balconies.
notes: Stake or cage for support. Feed regularly. Spanish varieties include Roma and Raf. Water consistently.

shortDescription: Productive vegetable plant with colorful sweet fruits. Essential in Spanish cuisine and gardens.
notes: Needs warm weather. Feed regularly. Includes sweet pimientos. Harvest regularly to encourage more fruit.

shortDescription: Spicy pepper plant producing hot fruits. Popular in Spanish cuisine, especially Padrón peppers.
notes: Spanish Padrón peppers are famous. Can be grown indoors in bright light. Handle hot varieties carefully.

shortDescription: Low-growing fruit plant producing sweet berries. Popular in Spanish balcony containers and gardens.
notes: Produces runners for propagation. Harvest regularly. Spain is major strawberry producer. Needs full sun.

shortDescription: Fast-growing salad green with many varieties. Easy to grow in Spanish balconies and gardens year-round.
notes: Harvest outer leaves for cut-and-come-again. Bolts in hot weather. Grow in cooler months in southern Spain.

shortDescription: Peppery salad green that grows quickly. Popular in Spanish cuisine and easy to grow in containers.
notes: Harvest young for milder flavor. Self-seeds readily. Grows best in cool weather. Called 'rúcula' in Spanish.

shortDescription: Nutritious leafy green with colorful stems. Common in Spanish vegetable gardens and markets.
notes: Harvest outer leaves. Heat-tolerant. Rainbow varieties are ornamental. Called 'acelga' in Spanish.

shortDescription: Nutritious leafy green vegetable. Easy to grow in Spanish gardens during cooler months.
notes: Grows best in cool weather. Bolts quickly in heat. Harvest outer leaves. Called 'espinaca' in Spanish.

shortDescription: Fast-growing root vegetable ready in weeks. Easy beginner vegetable in Spanish gardens.
notes: Ready to harvest in 3-4 weeks. Keep soil moist. Grows best in cool weather. Called 'rábano' in Spanish.

shortDescription: Essential culinary bulb crop. Fundamental in Spanish cuisine and easy to grow.
notes: Plant in autumn for summer harvest. Requires cold period. Spain is major garlic producer. Called 'ajo' in Spanish.
